docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama, seeking to pitch his plan for a health care overhaul, invited a group of white-coated doctors to the Rose Garden on Monday, telling them that ''nobody has more credibility with the American people on this issue than you do.'' In brief remarks to the doctors -- all of whom support Mr. Obama's plan and have vowed to fan out in their home states to promote it -- the president sought to make the case that overhauling the health care system would benefit the medical profession as much as it would patients.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama invites group of white-coated doctors to White House to pitch his plan for health care overhaul; in brief remarks to doctors, all of whom support president's plan and have vowed to promote it, Obama seeks to make case that overhauling health care system will benefit medical profession as much as patients; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For just one glimpse at why senators are anxiously awaiting the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office's cost estimate of the Finance Committee's health care bill, consider an amendment offered by Senator John D. Rockefeller IV. In its late-night race to complete debate on the legislation last Thursday, the committee accepted Mr. Rockefeller's amendment to continue the Children's Health Insurance Program, which is set to expire in 2013.
docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office cost analysis of Senate Finance Committee's health care bill could raise several questions about legislation; among concerns is Sen John D Rockefeller IV's amendment to continue Children's Health Insurance Program, which is set to expire in 2013; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Expanding health insurance to cover everyone over the age of 51 might help save costs to Medicare in the long run, according to a new study reported in The Annals of Internal Medicine. People between the ages of 51 and 65 who lack health insurance end up costing Medicare about $1,000 more per year when they turn 65 than people who have had coverage all along, the report says.
docs.abstract: Study finds that expanding health insurance to cover everyone over age 51 might help save costs to Medicare in long run; says people between 51 and 65 who lack health insurance end up costing Medicare about $1,000 more per year when they turn 65 than people who had coverage all along; report, whose principal investigators were J Michael McWilliams and John Ayanian of Harvard Medical School, appears in The Annals of Internal Medicine (M)
